div.p: This term is available within BIOGRAPHY or WRITING DIRECT PARENT . It describes a woman writer's purposes and reasons for writing (or choosing a particular genre or theme) which may be ascribed or self-identified, and may refer to textual motives or personal motives. See PATTITUDES for comparison. Material for this tag relies on sentiments expressed by the writer or the opinions of others (see Attribute values), or else on reasonable deduction. It has one optional attribute, MOTIVETYPE, with values of ascribed and self-identified.

div.codeblock: <PMOTIVES MOTIVETYPE="self-identified"> One afternoon while sitting by her mother's side "imprisoned by the heat of a summer afternoon," Joanna Baillie suddenly thought of writing drama.</PMOTIVES>

<PMOTIVES MOTIVETYPE="ascribed">Anne Barnard called the ballad "a little history of virtuous distress in a humble life" written in loneliness after her sister Margaret's reluctant marriage and perhaps owing something to that event.</PMOTIVES>
<PMOTIVES MOTIVETYPE="self-identified">Isabella Kelly wrote to support her family: "I had no resource but my pen."</PMOTIVES>
